natural problem: Given two real numbers $p>1$ and $q>1$ so that $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$, what is the value of $(p-1)(q-1)$?
natural solution: Multiplying both sides of the given equation by $p$, we see that $1+\frac{p}{q} = p \Rightarrow \frac{p}{q} = p-1 \Rightarrow p = q(p-1)$. But then $(p-1)(q-1) = q(p-1) - (p-1) = p -p +1 = \boxed{1}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: real
assumes h0 : "p > 1"
and h1 : "q > 1"
and h2 : "1 / p + 1 / q = 1"
shows  "(p - 1) * (q - 1) = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given two real numbers $p>1$ and $q>1$ so that $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$, what is the value of $(p-1)(q-1)$? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 Multiplying both sides of the given equation by $p$, we see that $1+\frac{p}{q} = p \Rightarrow \frac{p}{q} = p-1 \Rightarrow p = q(p-1)$. But then $(p-1)(q-1) = q(p-1) - (p-1) = p -p +1 = \boxed{1}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: real
assumes h0 : "p > 1"
and h1 : "q > 1"
and h2 : "1 / p + 1 / q = 1"
shows  "(p - 1) * (q - 1) = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If $p > 1$ and $q > 1$ satisfy the equation $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$, find the value of $(p - 1)(q - 1)$. The final answer is $1$.
